definitions.definition: Towards ; in the direction of.
examples: The astronauts headed for the moon.
Run for the hills!
He was headed for the door when he remembered.

definitions.definition: Directed at; intended to belong to.
examples: I have something for you.

definitions.definition: In order to help, benefit, gratify, honor etc. (someone or something).
examples: Everything I do, I do for you.
We're having a birthday party for Janet.
The mayor gave a speech for the charity gala.

definitions.definition: Befitting of someone’s beliefs, needs, wants, skills, or tastes; best suited to.
examples: If having to bag the groceries correctly is more than you can handle, then this isn't the job for you.

definitions.definition: To be used or treated in a stated way, or with a stated purpose.
examples: This is a new bell for my bicycle.
The cake is for Tom and Helen's anniversary.
This medicine is for your cough.
These apples here are for eating. The rest are for throwing away.
I'll buy something for killing cockroaches. We must find something to kill them all.

definitions.definition: Supporting , in favour of.
examples: All those for the motion, raise your hands.
Who's for ice-cream?
I'm for going by train
Ten voted for , and three against.

definitions.definition: Because of .
examples: He wouldn't apologize; and just for that, she refused to help him.
He looks better for having lost weight.
She was the worse for drink.
I like her for lots of reasons.

definitions.definition: In order to cure , remove or counteract .
examples: I need to spray my house for termites.

definitions.definition: So as to allow (something or someone) to take position.
examples: Make way for the president!
Clear the shelves for our new Christmas stock!

definitions.definition: In anticipation of.
examples: Stand by for your cue.
Prepare for battle.

definitions.definition: So as to identify or locate.
examples: They swept the area for enemy operatives.
Police combed his flat for clues.

definitions.definition: Over (a period of time).
examples: I've lived here for three years.
They fought for days over a silly pencil.
The store is closed for the day.

definitions.definition: Throughout or across (a distance in space).
examples: I can see for miles.

definitions.definition: Used to introduce a subject of a to-infinitive clause.
examples: It seems unreasonable for our boss to withhold our wages.
I don't think it's a good idea for you and me to meet.
For you and me to meet is not a good idea because I'm not eager for it to be a success.

definitions.definition: On behalf of.
examples: I will stand in for him.
I speak for the Prime Minister.

definitions.definition: In the role or capacity of; instead of; in place of.
examples: I used a hay bale for a bed.
He's got a turnip for a brain.

definitions.definition: In exchange for; in correspondence or equivalence with.
examples: I got five hundred pounds for that old car!
He matched me blow for blow.

definitions.definition: In order to obtain or acquire .
examples: I am aiming for completion by the end of business Thursday.
He's going for his doctorate.
Do you want to go for coffee?
People all over Greece looked to Delphi for answers.
Can you go to the store for some eggs?
I'm saving up for a car.
Don't wait for an answer.
What did he ask you for ?

definitions.definition: By the standards of, usually with the implication that those standards are lower than one might otherwise expect; considering.
examples: Fair for its day.
She's spry for an old lady.
He's very mature, for a two-year-old.

definitions.definition: To be , or as being.
examples: Don't take me for a fool.

definitions.definition: Despite , in spite of .
examples: For all his expensive education, he didn't seem very bright.
labels: usually in the phrase ' for all '
definitions.label_groups: usually in the phrase ' for all '

definitions.definition: Indicating something desired or anticipated.
examples: O for the wings of a dove.
Ah! for wings to soar …
And now for a slap-up meal!

definitions.definition: Introducing the first item(s) in a potential sequence .
examples: Go scuba diving? For one thing, I can't even swim.
For another, we don't have any equipment.
labels: in expressions such as ' for a start '
definitions.label_groups: in expressions such as ' for a start '

definitions.definition: In honor of; after.
examples: He is named for his grandfather.

definitions.definition: Due for or facing (a certain outcome or fate).
examples: He totally screwed up that project. Now he's surely for the sack.

definitions.definition: Out of ; used to indicate a fraction, a ratio
examples: In term of base hits, Jones was three for four on the day

definitions.definition: Used as part of a score to indicate the number of wickets that have fallen.
examples: At close of play, England were 305 for 3.

definitions.definition: Indicating that in prevention of which, or through fear of which, anything is done.
So ( that ), in order to

Used in various other more-or-less idiomatic ways to construe individual verbs, indicating various semantic relationships such as target, purpose, result, etc.; see also the entries for individual phrasal verbs, e.g. ask for , look for , stand for , etc.
examples: to account for one's whereabouts    to care for a relative    to settle for second best    to allow for mistakes
